inlineContent.text: Audio Unit, an exceptionally powerful polyphonic, multi-timbral sampler instrument which is built-in to both macOS and iOS. Unfortunately,
is far from perfect and not properly documented. This
is an attempt to provide an open-source alternative.
is nowhere near as powerful as
wrapper class, you should continue to use it.
provides three distinct mechanisms for loading samples:
allows use of sample data already in memory, e.g. data generated programmatically or read using custom file-reading code.
loads entire sets of samples by interpreting a simplistic subset of the “SFZ” soundfont file format.

take a “descriptor” argument (see next section below), whose many member variables define details like the sample’s natural MIDI note-number and pitch (frequency), plus details about loop start and end points, if used. For
allows all this “metadata” to be encoded in a SFZ file, using a simple plain-text format which is easy to understand and edit manually.
The mapping of MIDI (note number, velocity) pairs to samples is done using some internal lookup tables, which can be populated in one of two ways:
When your metadata includes min/max note-number and velocity values for all samples, call
to build a full key/velocity map.
If you only have note-numbers for each sample, call
to map each MIDI note-number (at any velocity) to the
Before loading a new group of samples, you must call
. Otherwise, the new samples will be loaded
to the already-loaded ones. This wastes memory and worse, newly-loaded samples will usually not sound at all, because the sampler simply plays the first matching sample it finds.
to load individual samples, you will need to create instances of one of three Swift structure types as follows.
The structures are defined as C structs in
folder in the main AudioKit repo). This file is simple enough to reproduce here:
By the miracle of Swift/Objective-C bridging (see
), each of these three structures is accessible from Swift as a similarly-named class, which you can create by simply providing values for all the properties, as you’ll see in the examples below.
property (as described above) plus several additional properties to provide all the information

is the sampling rate at which the sample data were acquired. If the sampler needs to play back the sample at a different rate, it will need to scale its playback rate based on the ratio of the two rates.

will be 1 if the sample is monophonic, or 2 if stereo. Note the sampler can play back mono samples as stereo; it simply plays the same data to both output channels. (In the reverse case, only the Left channel data will sound.)
only for stereo samples represented in memory as Left1, Right1, Left2, Right2, etc. Set
for mono samples, or non-interleaved stereo samples where all the Left samples come first, followed by all the Right samples.
is a pointer to the raw sample data; it has the slightly-scary Swift type

A few points to note about this example:
We get the scary-typed pointer by calling the pointer type’s
provides the current audio sampling rate
Since we have only one note, the
are normally sample counts (i.e., we could specify 0.0 and 999.0 to loop over the whole sample), but values between 0 and 1 are interpreted as
of the full sample length. Hence we can just use 0 to mean “start of the sample” and 1 to mean “end of the sample”.
to 0 also means “end of the sample”
To ensure the sampler keeps looping even after each note is released (very important with such short samples), we call
property, to which it simply adds a

abstract.text: is a new, polyphonic sample-playback engine built from scratch in C++.  It is 64-voice polyphonic and features a per-voice, stereo low-pass filter with resonance and ADSR envelopes for both amplitude and filter cutoff. Samples must be loaded into memory and remain resident there; it does not do streaming.  It reads standard audio files via
, as well as a more efficient
Stop the sampler playback of a specific note
Loop Thru Release (boolean, 0.0 for false or 1.0 for true)
isLegato (boolean, 0.0 for false or 1.0 for true)
